Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–7.

The table shows values of the expressions \(10x^2\) and \(2^x\).

\(x\) \(10x^2\) \(2^x\)
\(1\) \(10\) \(2\)
\(2\) \(40\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(90\) \(8\)
\(4\) \(160\) \(16\)
\(8\)    
\(10\)    
\(12\)    

  1. Complete the statements.
    1. When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(10x^2\):
      • Grows by increasing amounts but by decreasing growth factors.
      • Changes exponentially. It doubles.
      • Grows by decreasing amounts but by increasing growth factors.
      • Changes logarithmically. It has decreased by one-half.

ANSWER: Grows by increasing amounts but by decreasing growth factors.

    1. When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(2^x\):
      • Grows by increasing amounts but by decreasing growth factors.
      • Changes exponentially. It doubles.
      • Grows by decreasing amounts but by increasing growth factors.
      • Changes logarithmically. It has decreased by one-half.

ANSWER: Changes exponentially. It doubles.

  1. Will the value of \(10x^2\) be greater than or less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?
    • greater than
    • less than

ANSWER: greater than

  1. Will the value of \(2^x\) be greater than or less than \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?
    • greater than
    • less than

ANSWER: greater than

  1. Will the value of \(10x^2\) be greater than or less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?
    • greater than
    • less than

ANSWER: less than

  1. Determine the following values of \(10x^2\).
    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?

ANSWER: \(640\)

    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?

ANSWER: \(1000\)

    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?

ANSWER: \(1440\)

  1. Determine the following values of \(2^x\).
    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?

ANSWER: \(256\)

    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?

ANSWER: \(1024\)

    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?

ANSWER: \(4096\)

  1. Choose the best statement that describes how the values of the exponential expression \(2^x\) and the quadratic expression \(10x^2\) change as \(x\) becomes greater and greater.
    • The value of the exponential expression grows much more quickly as \(x\) increases.
    • The value of the quadratic expression grows much more quickly as \(x\) increases.
    • They both grow at the same rate.
    • There is no change in the values of the expressions when \(x\) increases.

ANSWER: The value of the exponential expression grows much more quickly as \(x\) increases.

  1. Answer the following questions about functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).
    1. What type of expression is \(f(x)=1.5^x\)?
      • exponential
      • quadratic
      • linear

ANSWER: exponential

    1. What type of expression is \(g(x)=500x^2+345x\)?
      • exponential
      • quadratic
      • linear

ANSWER: quadratic

    1. The values of which function will eventually be greater for larger and larger values of \(x\)?
      • Function \(f(x)\)
      • Function \(g(x)\)

ANSWER: Function \(f(x)\)

  1. What is the value of \(x\) when the exponential expression \(3(2)^x\) eventually overtakes the quadratic expression \(3x^2+2x\)?

ANSWER: \(5\)

  1. The table shows the values of \(4^x\) and \(100x^2\) for some values of \(x\).
\(x\) \(4^x\) \(100x^2\)
\(1\) \(4\) \(100\)
\(2\) \(16\) \(400\)
\(3\) \(64\) \(900\)
\(4\) \(256\) \(1,600\)
\(5\) \(1,024\) \(2,500\)

Looking at the patterns in the table, choose the best answer to explain why, as the value of \(x\) increases, the values of the exponential expression \(4^x\) will eventually overtake the values of the quadratic expression \(100x^2\).

    • The value of \(100x^2\) grows by different factors, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by a factor of \(4\) every time.
    • The value of \(100x^2\) grows by a factor of \(4\) every time, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by different factors.
    • The value of \(100x^2\) grows by different factors, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by a factor of \(x\) every time.
    • The value of \(100x^2\) grows by a factor of \(x\) every time, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by different factors.

ANSWER: The value of \(100x^2\) grows by different factors, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by a factor of \(4\) every time.
